author: Sophie Campbell
title: The 10 best family days out from London
text: Follow the links below to see the rest of our guide • The best family days out from Manchester • The best family days out from Birmingham • The best family days out from Bristol • The best family days out from Newcastle Adventure Zone Surrey Outdoor Learning and Development has four activity centres, two of which (Thames Young Mariners, in Ham, and High Ashurst, in Box Hill) are within an hour of London. Their family activity days involve varying degrees of adrenalin: for instance, you can climb, abseil and complete high ropes courses, or combine archery, woodland skills and the challenge course (with navigation and orienteering) at High Ashurst. There must be one participating adult with up to three children. 01372 378901; surreyoutdoorlearning.uk ; adult £37.50, child £27.50. Camping skiffs Just a 25-minute train ride from Waterloo to Walton-on-Thames, and a five-minute taxi ride from there, adventure from another era awaits. Edwardian skiffs convert into floating tents by green canvas over iron hoops, producing an aquarium-like atmosphere. This is your chance to reproduce the hapless delights of Three Men in a Boat, but it’s also a way of teaching children to row and to discover the Thames. Bring supplies and bedding. The route has plenty of pubs, so there is no need for cooking gear. There is no minimum age, but young children must be supervised at all times. 01932 232433; skiffhire.com ; four days in a skiff with tent for up to four people, starting and finishing at Walton-on-Thames, from £460. • 50 great days out in the UK • Holiday complaints: what to do when things go wrong • How to survive a long car journey with children Freecycle guided cycle rides This free family cycling weekend (on August 1-2) transforms London into a sea of high-visibility vests as children bomb about on their bicycles for a closed-road festival. London Cycling Campaign members lead slow rides into the Prudential Ride London from each borough. Head to Harrow, Havering or Richmond for a greener, more challenging ride. 020 7902 0212; prudentialridelondon.co.uk A deer in Richmond Park Photo: AP/FOTOLIA Go Ape! Trent Park Swing your way through the trees, teeter along on rope walkways and zoom from canopy to forest floor on zipwires, all within reach of Cockfosters Tube station. There are twin courses, so the park can handle large numbers of visitors, and it is open every day during the summer holidays. “Mini Tarzans” must be over 3ft 4in (1m) tall and over the age of six. Younger children can use the small playground and café while their siblings behave like primates. 0333 331 7620; goape.co.uk/days-out/trent-park ; children 16-plus £31, 10-15 £25, 6-9 £18. • The 20 best hidden beaches in the UK • How to survive a family trip to the zoo • Flying with children: 10 secrets to stress-free travel London Outer Orbital Path This 150-mile circular walk around London celebrates its 15th birthday next year. Transport for London has an excellent webpage devoted to the Loop’s 24 sections and how to reach them. The 3½-mile-long Banstead Downs-to-Ewell section is suitable for all ages, and ambles through Henry VIII’s old deer park at Nonsuch Palace – long demolished – and by the tiny 18th-century jail and fire station in Ewell.  0343222 1234; tfl.gov.uk/modes/ walking/loop-walk . Lee Valley Water Centre If you haven’t been to the paddling venue for the London 2012 Olympics yet, it’s time to hop on a northbound train for 40 minutes and check it out. The white-water “mountain” is too extreme for beginners – though if you can get enough people together, you can hire a raft and guide to crash down the course – but the site offers great-value lake kayaking and canoeing taster courses for families (minimum age: eight years). 08456 770606; gowhitewater.co.uk ; taster sessions £10 per person; canoe hire £5 per hour. Rafts on the Olympic course (minimum age 14) £35 per person. There are serious rapids at Lee Valley Water Centre Photo: GETTY Ruislip Park Stables This friendly stables, near Pinner (accessible via the Piccadilly or Metropolitan lines), takes riders of all levels out for a hack through the hornbeam, oak and beech landscape of Ruislip Woods National Nature Reserve, the largest single area of woodland in Greater London. Inexperienced riders can be led. Although hats are provided, boots are not, so wear shoes with a low heel. 01895 676051; ruislipparkstables.co.uk ; half-hour ride £20, one hour £30 per person. Ruislip Woods National Nature Reserve, the largest single area of woodland in Greater London Photo: ALAMY Go fishing Just a 30-minute drive from central London, or 10 minutes’ walk from Northolt Underground, these six council-run fishing lakes have a team of coaches who offer lessons every day from 9am to 7pm, the cost of which includes tackle, bait and licences. The waters teem with roach, tench, perch and chub, and you can haul as many as 20 fish out of the water every hour – catch and release, of course. With free parking and a playground. 07515 006007; fishinglondon.co.uk ; two hours £75 per person, four hours £150 for two. Chislehurst Caves When it pours, take a trip into the subterranean world to explore this 14-acre complex of man-made caves, originally dug out for lime and flints. They have also served as munitions storage, mushroom beds, a vast air raid shelter and a jazz club. The caves are said to be haunted, which adds to the creepy fun. The hour-long guided tours run from Wednesday to Sunday, from 10am to 4pm, leaving on the hour, every hour. 020 8467 3264; chislehurst-caves.co.uk ; adult £6, senior and child (3-15) £4 Chislehurst Caves is a man-made 14-acre complex Photo: ALAMY Beach volleyball Park the family by the sea for the day and rent a beach volleyball court from Yellowave, in Brighton (a 55-minute train ride from London). Smaller children will love the playground next to the Barefoot Café, and this summer you can book taster sessions for beach rugby, football and volleyball for three age groups: 6-8, 8-12 and 13-15. 01273 672222; yellowave.co.uk ; courts £21 per hour; children’s taster sessions from £5.80.
